clinical_study.brief_title: Corneal Epithelial Autograft for Limbal Dermoid
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial of Corneal Epithelial Autograft for Limbal Dermoid

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to explore whether femtosecond laser-assisted corneal epithelial autograft is more effective than femtosecond laser-assisted limbal autograft for ocular surface reconstruction after excision of limbal dermoid.

primary_outcome.description: Restoration of a completely epithelized, stable, and avascular corneal surface.

secondary_outcome.description: A grading system from 0 to 4 with slit-lamp photographs will be used to determine cosmetic result of each graft.
To measure corneal thickness using anterior segment optical coherence tomography.
To measure best corrected visual acuity using ETDRS chart or Teller Acuity Cards.
To measure the changes of corneal power, astigmatism and aberration using autorefractor keratometer and wavefront aberrometer respectively.

secondary_outcome.measure: Density of stromal nerve and stromal keratocytes
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the stromal nerve and stromal keratocytes using in vivo confocal microscopy.
To assess corneal haze using in vivo confocal microscopy.

arm_group.description: Corneal dermoid tumor resection combined with femtosecond laser assisted corneal epithelial autograft
Corneal dermoid tumor resection combined with femtosecond laser assisted limbal autograft

intervention.description: After removal of the recipient's diseased dermoid, a size-match donor epithelial tissue will be obtained from the healthy area of the same eye (corneal epithelial autograft) using femtosecond laser technology, with the goal of closure of bare stromal area by sutured corneal epithelial tissue to ensure the integrity of ocular surface. This closure may also create a microenvironment that stimulates stromal cells' regenerative capacity and regulates their epithelial-mesenchymal transition process.
A commercial femtosecond laser to create a particular shaped graft for transplantation
Simple dermoid excision will be performed, followed by closure of the bare sclera by sutured femtosecond laser-assisted limbal autograft.
A commercial femtosecond laser to create a particular shaped graft for transplantation
